Fault-Tolerant Federated Reinforcement Learning with Theoretical Guarantee

Flint Xiaofeng Fan {xiaofeng,daizhongxiang,lowkh}@comp.nus.edu.sg,2yiningma@u.nus.edu {stufanxf,cheston-tan}@i2r.a-star.edu.sg,4jw334405@alibaba-inc.com Yining Ma Dept. of ISEM, National University of Singapore, Republic of Singapore Zhongxiang Dai {xiaofeng,daizhongxiang,lowkh}@comp.nus.edu.sg,2yiningma@u.nus.edu Wei Jing Alibaba DAMO Academy, Hangzhou, China
Cheston Tan {stufanxf,cheston-tan}@i2r.a-star.edu.sg,4jw334405@alibaba-inc.com Bryan Kian Hsiang Low {xiaofeng,daizhongxiang,lowkh}@comp.nus.edu.sg,2yiningma@u.nus.edu
Abstract

The growing literature of Federated Learning (FL) has recently inspired Federated Reinforcement Learning (FRL) to encourage multiple agents to federatively build a better decision-making policy without sharing raw trajectories. Despite its promising applications, existing works on FRL fail to I) provide theoretical analysis on its convergence, and II) account for random system failures and adversarial attacks. Towards this end, we propose the first FRL framework the convergence of which is guaranteed and tolerant to less than half of the participating agents being random system failures or adversarial attackers. We prove that the sample efficiency of the proposed framework is guaranteed to improve with the number of agents and is able to account for such potential failures or attacks. All theoretical results are empirically verified on various RL benchmark tasks. Our code is available at https://github.com/flint-xf-fan/Byzantine-Federeated-RL.

1 Introduction

Reinforcement learning (RL) has recently been applied to many real-world decision-making problems such as gaming, robotics, healthcare, etc. [1, 2, 3]. However, despite its impressive performances in simulation, RL often suffers from poor sample efficiency, which hinders its success in real-world applications [4, 5]. For example, when RL is applied to provide clinical decision support [6, 3, 7], its performance is limited by the number (i.e., sample size) of admission records possessed by a hospital, which cannot be synthetically generated [3]. As this challenge is usually faced by many agents (e.g., different hospitals), a natural solution is to encourage multiple RL agents to share their trajectories, to collectively build a better decision-making policy that one single agent can not obtain by itself. However, in many applications, raw RL trajectories contain sensitive information (e.g., the medical records contain sensitive information about patients) and thus sharing them is prohibited. To this end, the recent success of Federated Learning (FL) [8, 9, 10, 11] has inspired the setting of Federated Reinforcement Learning (FRL) [12], which aims to federatively build a better policy from multiple RL agents without requiring them to share their raw trajectories. FRL is practically appealing for addressing the sample inefficiency of RL in real systems, such as autonomous driving [13], fast personalization [14], optimal control of IoT devices [15], robots navigation [16], and resource management in networking [17]. Despite its promising applications, FRL is faced by a number of major challenges, which existing works are unable to tackle.

Firstly, existing FRL frameworks are not equipped with theoretical convergence guarantee, and thus lack an assurance for the sample efficiency of practical FRL applications, which is a critical drawback due to the high sampling cost of RL trajectories in real systems [4]. Unlike FL where training data can be collected offline, FRL requires every agent to sample trajectories by interacting with the environment during learning. However, interacting with real systems can be slow, expensive, or fragile. This makes it critical for FRL to be sample-efficient and hence highlights the requirement for convergence guarantee of FRL, without which no assurance on its sample efficiency is provided for practical applications. To fill this gap, we establish on recent endeavors in stochastic variance-reduced optimization techniques to develop a variance-reduced federated policy gradient framework, the convergence of which is guaranteed. We prove that the proposed framework enjoys a sample complexity of O​(1/ϵ5/3)𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53O(1/\epsilon^{5/3}) to converge to an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary point in the single-agent setting, which matches recent results of variance-reduced policy gradient [18, 19]. More importantly, the aforementioned sample complexity is guaranteed to improve at a rate of O​(1/K2/3)𝑂1superscript𝐾23O(1/K^{2/3}) upon the federation of K𝐾K agents. This guarantees that an agent achieves a better sample efficiency by joining the federation and benefits from more participating agents, which are highly desirable in FRL.

Another challenge inherited from FL is that FRL is vulnerable to random failures or adversarial attacks, which poses threats to many real-world RL systems. For example, robots may behave arbitrarily due to random hardware issues; clinical data may provide inaccurate records and hence create misleading trajectories [3]; autonomous vehicles, on which RL is commonly deployed, are subject to adversarial attacks [20]. As we will show in experiments, including such random failures or adversary agents in FRL can significantly deteriorate its convergence or even result in unlearnability. Of note, random failures and adversarial attacks in FL systems are being encompassed by the Byzantine failure model [21], which is considered as the most stringent fault formalism in distributed computing [22, 23] – a small fraction of agents may behave arbitrarily and possibly adversarially, with the goal of breaking or at least slowing down the convergence of the system. As algorithms proven to be correct in this setting are guaranteed to converge under arbitrary system behavior (e.g., exercising failures or being attacked) [9, 24], we study the fault tolerance of our proposed FRL framework using the Byzantine failure model. We design a gradient-based Byzantine filter on top of the variance-reduced federated policy gradient framework. We show that, when a certain percentage (denoted by α<0.5𝛼0.5\alpha<0.5) of agents are Byzantine agents, the sample complexity of the FRL system is worsened by only an additive term of O​(α4/3/ϵ5/3)𝑂superscript𝛼43superscriptitalic-ϵ53O(\alpha^{4/3}/\epsilon^{5/3}) (Section 4). Therefore, when α→0→𝛼0\alpha\rightarrow 0, (i.e., an ideal system with zero chance of failure), the filter induces no impact on the convergence.

Contributions. In this paper, we study the federated reinforcement learning problem with theoretical guarantee in the potential presence of faulty agents, as illustrated in Fig. 1. We introduce Federated Policy Gradient with Byzantine Resilience (FedPG-BR), the first FRL framework that is theoretically principled and practically effective for the FRL setting, accounting for random systematic failures and adversarial attacks. In particular, FedPG-BR (a) enjoys a guaranteed sample complexity which improves with more participating agents, and (b) is tolerant to the Byzantine fault in both theory and practice. We discuss the details of problem setting and the technical challenges (Section 3) and provide theoretical analysis of FedPG-BR (Section 4). We also demonstrate its empirical efficacy on various RL benchmark tasks (Section 5).

2 Background

Stochastic Variance-Reduced Gradient aims to solve min𝜽∈ℝd⁡[J​(𝜽)≜1B​∑i=1BJi​(𝜽)]subscript𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑≜𝐽𝜽1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐵subscript𝐽𝑖𝜽\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}[J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}J_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})]. Under the common assumption of all function components Jisubscript𝐽𝑖J_{i} being smooth and convex in 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, gradient descent (GD) achieves linear convergence in the number of iterations of parameter updates [25, 26]. However, every iteration of GD requires B𝐵B gradient computations, which can be expensive for large B𝐵B. To overcome this problem, stochastic GD (SGD) [27, 28] samples a single data point per iteration, which incurs lower per-iteration cost yet results in a sub-linear convergence rate [29]. For a better trade-off between convergence rate and per-iteration computational cost, the stochastic variance-reduced gradient (SVRG) method has been proposed, which reuses past gradient computations to reduce the variance of the current gradient estimate [30, 31, 32, 33]. More recently, stochastically controlled stochastic gradient (SCSG) has been proposed for convex [34] or smooth non-convex objective function [35], to further reduce the computational cost of SVRG especially when required ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small in finding ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate solution. Refer to Appendix A.1 for more details on SVRG and SCSG.

Reinforcement Learning (RL) can be modelled as a discrete-time Markov Decision Process (MDP) [36]: M≜{𝒮,𝒜,𝒫,ℛ,γ,ρ}≜𝑀𝒮𝒜𝒫ℛ𝛾𝜌M\triangleq\{\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},\mathcal{P},\mathcal{R},\gamma,\rho\}. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} represents the state space, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is the action space, 𝒫​(s′|s,a)𝒫conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎\mathcal{P}(s^{\prime}|s,a) defines the transition probability from state s𝑠s to s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime} after taking action a𝑎a, ℛ​(s,a):𝒮×𝒜↦[0,R]:ℛ𝑠𝑎maps-to𝒮𝒜0𝑅\mathcal{R}(s,a):\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}\mapsto[0,R] is the reward function for state-action pair (s,a)𝑠𝑎(s,a) and some constant R>0𝑅0R>0, γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1) is the discount factor, and ρ𝜌\rho is the initial state distribution. An agent’s behavior is controlled by a policy π𝜋\pi, where π​(a|s)𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠\pi(a|s) defines the probability that the agent chooses action a𝑎a at state s𝑠s. We consider episodic MDPs with trajectory horizon H𝐻H. A trajectory τ≜{s0,a0,s1,a1,…,sH−1,aH−1}≜𝜏subscript𝑠0subscript𝑎0subscript𝑠1subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑠𝐻1subscript𝑎𝐻1\tau\triangleq\{s_{0},a_{0},s_{1},a_{1},...,s_{H-1},a_{H-1}\} is a sequence of state-action pairs traversed by an agent following any stationary policy, where s0∼ρsimilar-tosubscript𝑠0𝜌s_{0}\sim\rho. ℛ​(τ)≜∑t=0H−1γt​ℛ​(st,at)≜ℛ𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐻1superscript𝛾𝑡ℛsubscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑎𝑡\mathcal{R}(\tau)\triangleq\sum_{t=0}^{H-1}\gamma^{t}\mathcal{R}\left(s_{t},a_{t}\right) gives the cumulative discounted reward for a trajectory τ𝜏\tau.

Policy Gradient (PG) methods have achieved impressive successes in model-free RL [37, 38, etc.]. Compared with deterministic value-function based methods such as Q-learning, PG methods are generally more effective in high-dimensional problems and enjoy the flexibility of stochasticity. In PG, we use π𝜽subscript𝜋𝜽\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} to denote the policy parameterized by 𝜽∈ℝd𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (e.g., a neural network), and p​(τ|π𝜽)𝑝conditional𝜏subscript𝜋𝜽p(\tau|\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) to represent the trajectory distribution induced by policy π𝜽subscript𝜋𝜽\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}. For brevity, we use θ𝜃\theta to denote the corresponding policy π𝜽subscript𝜋𝜽\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}. The performance of a policy 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} can be measured by J​(𝜽)≜𝔼τ∼p(⋅|𝜽)​[ℛ​(τ)|M]J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta})}[\mathcal{R}(\tau)|M]. Taking the gradient of J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) with respect to 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} gives

∇𝜽J​(𝜽)=∫τℛ​(τ)​∇𝜽p​(τ∣𝜽)​dτ=𝔼τ∼p(⋅∣𝜽)​[∇𝜽log⁡p​(τ∣𝜽)​ℛ​(τ)∣M]\displaystyle\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}J(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\int_{\tau}\mathcal{R}(\tau)\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}p(\tau\mid\boldsymbol{\theta})\mathrm{d}\tau=\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p(\cdot\mid\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\log p(\tau\mid\boldsymbol{\theta})\mathcal{R}(\tau)\mid M\right] (1)

Then, the policy 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} can be optimized by gradient ascent. Since computing (1) is usually prohibitive, stochastic gradient ascent is typically used. In each iteration, we sample a batch of trajectories {τi}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖1𝐵\{\tau_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B} using the current policy 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, and update the policy by 𝜽←𝜽+η​∇^B​J​(𝜽)←𝜽𝜽𝜂subscript^∇𝐵𝐽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}\leftarrow\boldsymbol{\theta}+\eta\widehat{\nabla}_{B}J\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right), where η𝜂\eta is the step size and ∇^B​J​(𝜽)subscript^∇𝐵𝐽𝜽\widehat{\nabla}_{B}J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is an estimate of (1) using the sampled trajectories {τi}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖1𝐵\{\tau_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B}: ∇^B​J​(𝜽)=1B​∑i=1B∇𝜽log⁡p​(τi∣𝜽)​ℛ​(τi)subscript^∇𝐵𝐽𝜽1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐵subscript∇𝜽𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑖𝜽ℛsubscript𝜏𝑖\widehat{\nabla}_{B}J(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\log p\left(\tau_{i}\mid\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\mathcal{R}\left(\tau_{i}\right). The most common policy gradient estimators, such as REINFORCE [39] and GPOMDP [40], can be expressed as

∇^B​J​(𝜽)=1B​∑i=1Bg​(τi|𝜽)subscript^∇𝐵𝐽𝜽1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐵𝑔conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑖𝜽\widehat{\nabla}_{B}J(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}g(\tau_{i}|\boldsymbol{\theta}) (2)

where τi={s0i,a0i,s1i,a1i,…,sH−1i,aH−1i}subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑎0𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑎1𝑖…superscriptsubscript𝑠𝐻1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑎𝐻1𝑖\tau_{i}=\{s_{0}^{i},a_{0}^{i},s_{1}^{i},a_{1}^{i},\ldots,s_{H-1}^{i},a_{H-1}^{i}\} and g​(τi|𝜽)𝑔conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑖𝜽g(\tau_{i}|\boldsymbol{\theta}) is an unbiased estimate of ∇𝜽log⁡p​(τi∣𝜽)​ℛ​(τi)subscript∇𝜽𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑖𝜽ℛsubscript𝜏𝑖\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\log p(\tau_{i}\mid\boldsymbol{\theta})\mathcal{R}(\tau_{i}). We provide formal definition of g​(τi|𝜽)𝑔conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑖𝜽g(\tau_{i}|\boldsymbol{\theta}) in Appendix A.2.

SVRPG. A key issue for PG is the high variance of the estimator based on stochastic gradients (2) which results in slow convergence. Similar to SGD for finite-sum optimization, PG requires O​(1/ϵ2)𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(1/\epsilon^{2}) trajectories to find an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary point such that 𝔼​[‖∇J​(𝜽)‖2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐽𝜽2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon [19]. That is, PG typically requires a large number of trajectories to find a well-performing policy. To reduce the variance of the gradient estimator in PG (2), SVRG has been applied to policy evaluation [41, 42] and policy optimization [43]. The work of Papini et al. [18] has adapted the theoretical analysis of SVRG to PG to introduce the stochastic variance-reduced PG (SVRPG) algorithm. More recently, Xu et al. [19] has refined the analysis of SVRPG [18] and shown that SVRPG enjoys a sample complexity of O​(1/ϵ5/3)𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53O(1/\epsilon^{5/3}). These works have demonstrated both theoretically and empirically that SVRG is a promising approach to reduce the variance and thus improve the sample efficiency of PG methods.

Fault tolerance refers to the property that enables a computing system to continue operating properly without interruption when one or more of its workers fail. Among the many fault formalisms, the Byzantine failure model has a rich history in distributed computing [22, 23] and is considered as the most stringent fault formalism in fault-tolerant FL system design [9, 24]. Originated from the Byzantine generals problem [21], the Byzantine failure model allows an α𝛼\alpha-fraction (typical α<0.5𝛼0.5\alpha<0.5) of workers to behave arbitrarily and possibly adversarially, with the goal of breaking or at least slowing down the convergence of the algorithm. As algorithms proven to be resilient to the Byzantine failures are guaranteed to converge under arbitrary system behavior (hence fault-tolerant) [22, 23], it has motivated a significant interest in providing distributed supervised learning with Byzantine resilience guarantees [e.g., 44, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49]. However, there is yet no existing work studying the correctness of Byzantine resilience in the context of FRL.

3 Fault-tolerant federated reinforcement learning

3.1 Problem statement

Our problem setting is similar to that of FL [8] where a central server is assumed to be trustworthy and governs the federation of K𝐾K distributed agents k∈{1,…,K}𝑘1…𝐾k\in\{1,...,K\}. In each round t∈{1,…,T}𝑡1…𝑇t\in\{1,...,T\}, the central server broadcasts its parameter 𝜽0tsuperscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t} to all agents. Each agent then independently samples a batch of trajectories {τt,i(k)}i=1Btsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜏𝑘𝑡𝑖𝑖1subscript𝐵𝑡\{\tau^{(k)}_{t,i}\}_{i=1}^{B_{t}} by interacting with the environment using the obtained policy, e.g., {τt,i(k)}i=1Bt∼p(⋅|𝜽0t)\{\tau^{(k)}_{t,i}\}_{i=1}^{B_{t}}\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}). However, different from FL where each agent computes the parameter updates and sends the updated parameter to the server for aggregation [8], agents in our setup do not compute the updates locally, but instead send the gradient computed w.r.t. their local trajectories μt(k)≜∇^Bt​J​(𝜽0t)≜subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑘𝑡subscript^∇subscript𝐵𝑡𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\mu^{(k)}_{t}\triangleq\widehat{\nabla}_{B_{t}}J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) directly to the server. The server then aggregates the gradients, performs a policy update step, and starts a new round of federation.

Of note, every agent including the server is operating in a separate copy of the MDP. No exchange of raw trajectories is required, and no communication between any two agents is allowed. To account for potential failures and attacks, we allow an α𝛼\alpha-fraction of agents to be Byzantine agents with α∈[0,0.5)𝛼00.5\alpha\in[0,0.5). That is, in each round t𝑡t, a good agent always sends its computed μt(k)subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑘𝑡\mu^{(k)}_{t} back to the server, while a Byzantine agent may return any arbitrary vector.111A Byzantine agent may not be Byzantine in every round. The server has no information regarding whether Byzantine agents exist and cannot track the communication history with any agent. In every round, the server can only access the K𝐾K gradients received from agents, and thereby uses them to detect Byzantine agents so that it only aggregates the gradients from those agents that are believed to be non-Byzantine agents.

Notations. Following the notations of SCSG [35], we use 𝜽0tsuperscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t} to denote the server’s initial parameter in round t𝑡t and 𝜽ntsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t} to represent the updated parameter at the n𝑛n-th step in round t𝑡t. τt,i(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑖𝑘\tau_{t,i}^{(k)} represents agent k𝑘k’s i𝑖i-th trajectory sampled using 𝜽0tsubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡0\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}_{0}. ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| denotes Euclidean norm and Spectral norms for vectors and matrices, respectively. O​(⋅)𝑂⋅O(\cdot) hides all constant terms.

3.2 Technical challenges

There is an emerging interest in Byzantine-resilient distributed supervised learning [e.g., 44, 50, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49]. However, a direct application of those works to FRL is not possible due to that the objective function J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) of RL, which is conditioned on τ∼p(⋅|𝜽)\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}), is different from the supervised classification loss seen in the aforementioned works, resulting in the following issues:

Non-stationarity: unlike in supervised learning, the distribution of RL trajectories is affected by the value of the policy parameter which changes over time (e.g., τ∼p(⋅|𝜽)\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta})). We deal with the non-stationarity using importance sampling [51] (Section 3.3).

Non-concavity: the objective function J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is typically non-concave. To derive the theoretical results accounting for the non-concavity, we need the L𝐿L-smoothness assumption on J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}), which is a reasonable assumption and commonly made in the literature [52] (Section 4). Hence we aim to find an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate solution (i.e., a commonly used objective in non-convex optimization):

Definition 1 (ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate solution).

A point 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta} is called ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary if ‖∇J​(𝛉)‖2≤ϵsuperscriptnorm∇𝐽𝛉2italic-ϵ\|\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|^{2}\leq\epsilon. Moreover, the algorithm is said to achieve an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate solution in t𝑡t rounds if 𝔼​[‖∇J​(𝛉)‖2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐽𝛉2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon, where the expectation is with respect to all randomness of the algorithm until round t𝑡t.

High variance in gradient estimation: the high variance in estimating (2) renders the FRL system vulnerable to variance-based attacks which conventional Byzantine-resilient optimization works fail to defend [47]. To combat this issue, we adapt the SCSG optimization [35] to federated policy gradient for a refined control over the estimation variance, hence enabling the following assumption which we exploit to design our Byzantine filtering step:

Assumption 2 (On bounded variance of the gradient estimator).

There is a constant σ𝜎\sigma such that ∥g(τ|𝛉)−∇J(𝛉)∥≤σ\|g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq\sigma for any τ∼p​(τ|𝛉)similar-to𝜏𝑝conditional𝜏𝛉\tau\sim p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}) for all policy π𝛉subscript𝜋𝛉\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}.

Remark.

Assumption 2 is also seen in Byzantine-resilient optimization [46, 48] and may be relaxed to 𝔼∥g(τ|𝛉)−∇J(𝛉)∥≤𝛉\mathbb{E}\|g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq\boldsymbol{\theta} which is a standard assumption commonly used in stochastic non-convex optimization [e.g. 53, 35]. In this work, the value of σ𝜎\sigma is the maximum difference between optimal gradient ∇J​(𝛉)∇𝐽𝛉\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) and the gradient estimate g​(τ|𝛉)𝑔conditional𝜏𝛉g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta)} w.r.t. any trajectories induced by policy π𝛉subscript𝜋𝛉\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}. For complex real-world problems with continuous, high-dimensional controls, σ𝜎\sigma may be upper-bounded, provided that the MDP is Lipschitz continuousPirotta et al. [52]. The deviation can be obtained by referring to Proposition 2 of Pirotta et al. [52].222The value of σ𝜎\sigma can be estimated at the server.

3.3 Algorithm description

The pseudocode for the proposed Federated Policy Gradient with Byzantine Resilience (FedPG-BR) is shown in Algorithm 1. FedPG-BR starts with a randomly initialized parameter 𝜽~0subscript~𝜽0\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0} at the server. At the beginning of the t𝑡t-th round, the server keeps a snapshot of its parameter from the previous round (i.e., 𝜽0t←𝜽~t−1←superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}\leftarrow\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t-1}) and broadcasts this parameter to all agents (line 3). Every (good) agent k𝑘k samples Btsubscript𝐵𝑡B_{t} trajectories {τt,i(k)}i=1Btsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑖𝑘𝑖1subscript𝐵𝑡\{\tau_{t,i}^{(k)}\}_{i=1}^{B_{t}} using the policy 𝜽0tsuperscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t} (line 5), computes a gradient estimate μt(k)≜1/Bt​∑i=1Btg​(τt,i(k)|𝜽0t)≜superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘1subscript𝐵𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐵𝑡𝑔conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\mu_{t}^{(k)}\triangleq 1/B_{t}\sum_{i=1}^{B_{t}}g(\tau_{t,i}^{(k)}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) where g𝑔g is either the REINFORCE or the GPOMDP estimator (line 6), and sends μt(k)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘\mu_{t}^{(k)} back to the server. For a Byzantine agent, it can send an arbitrary vector instead of the correct gradient estimate. After all gradients are received, the server performs the Byzantine filtering step, and then computes the batch gradient μtsubscript𝜇𝑡\mu_{t} by averaging those gradients that the server believes are from non-Byzantine agents (line 7). For better clarity, we present the subroutine FedPG-Aggregate for Byzantine filtering and gradient aggregation in Algorithm 1.1, which we discuss in detail separately.

The aggregation is then followed by the SCSG inner loop [35] with Ntsubscript𝑁𝑡N_{t} steps, where Ntsubscript𝑁𝑡N_{t} is sampled from a geometric distribution with parameter BtBt+btsubscript𝐵𝑡subscript𝐵𝑡subscript𝑏𝑡\frac{B_{t}}{B_{t}+b_{t}} (line 8). At step n𝑛n, the server independently samples btsubscript𝑏𝑡b_{t} (bt≪Btmuch-less-thansubscript𝑏𝑡subscript𝐵𝑡b_{t}\ll B_{t}) trajectories {τn,jt}j=1btsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑗𝑡𝑗1subscript𝑏𝑡\{\tau_{n,j}^{t}\}_{j=1}^{b_{t}} using its current policy 𝜽ntsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t} (line 10), and then updates the policy parameter 𝜽ntsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t} based on the following semi-stochastic gradient (lines 11 and 12):

vnt≜1bt​∑j=1bt[g​(τn,jt|𝜽nt)−ω​(τn,jt|𝜽nt,𝜽0t)​g​(τn,jt|𝜽0t)]+μt.≜superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝑡1subscript𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑏𝑡delimited-[]𝑔conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡𝜔conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝑔conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡subscript𝜇𝑡\displaystyle v_{n}^{t}\triangleq\frac{1}{b_{t}}\sum_{j=1}^{b_{t}}\left[g(\tau_{n,j}^{t}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t})-\omega(\tau_{n,j}^{t}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})g(\tau_{n,j}^{t}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\right]+\mu_{t}. (3)

The last two terms serve as a correction to the gradient estimate to reduce variance and improve the convergence rate of Algorithm 1. Of note, the semi-stochastic gradient above (3) differs from that used in SCSG due to the additional term of ω​(τ|𝜽nt,𝜽0t)≜p​(τ|𝜽0t)/p​(τ|𝜽nt)≜𝜔conditional𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝑝conditional𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝑝conditional𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\triangleq p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})/p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t}). This term is known as the importance weight from p​(τ|𝜽nt)𝑝conditional𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t}) to p​(τ|𝜽0t)𝑝conditional𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) to account for the aforementioned non-stationarity of the distribution in RL [18, 19]. In particular, directly computing g​(τn,jt|𝜽0t)𝑔conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡g(\tau_{n,j}^{t}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) results in a biased estimation because the trajectories {τn,jt}j=1btsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑗𝑡𝑗1subscript𝑏𝑡\{\tau_{n,j}^{t}\}_{j=1}^{b_{t}} are sampled from the policy 𝜽ntsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t} instead of 𝜽0tsuperscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}. We prove in Lemma 8 (Appendix E) that this importance weight results in an unbiased estimate of the gradient, i.e., 𝔼τ∼p(⋅∣𝜽n)​[ω​(τ|𝜽n,𝜽0)​g​(τ|𝜽0)]=∇J​(𝜽0)\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p\left(\cdot\mid\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}\right)}[\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})]=\nabla J({\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}).

Here we describe the details of our Byzantine filtering step (i.e., the subroutine FedPG-Aggregate in Algorithm 1.1), which is inspired by the works of Alistarh et al. [46] and Khanduri et al. [48] in distributed supervised learning. In any round t𝑡t, we use 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} to denote the set of true good agents and use 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} to denote the set of agents that are believed to be good by the server. Our Byzantine filtering consists of two filtering rules denoted by R1 (lines 2-4) and R2 (lines 6-8). R2 is more intuitive to understand, so we start by introducing R2. Firstly, in line 6, the server constructs a set S2subscript𝑆2S_{2} of vector medians [46] where each element of S2subscript𝑆2S_{2} is chosen from {μt(k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mu_{t}^{(k)}\}_{k=1}^{K} if it is close (within 2​σ2𝜎2\sigma in Euclidean distance) to more than K/2𝐾2K/2 elements. Next, the server finds a Mean of Median vector μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\text{mom}} from S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}, which is defined as any μt(k~)∈S2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡~𝑘subscript𝑆2\mu_{t}^{(\tilde{k})}\in S_{2} that is the closet to the mean of the vectors in S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}. After μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\text{mom}} is selected, the server can construct the set 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} by filtering out any μt(k)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘\mu_{t}^{(k)} whose distance to μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\text{mom}} is larger than 2​σ2𝜎2\sigma (line 8). This filtering rule is designed based on Assumption 2 which implies that the maximum distance between any two good agents is 2​σ2𝜎2\sigma, and our assumption that at least half of the agents are good (i.e., α<0.5𝛼0.5\alpha<0.5). We show in Appendix D that under these two assumptions, R2 guarantees that all good agents are included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} (i.e., |𝒢t|≥(1−α)​Ksubscript𝒢𝑡1𝛼𝐾|\mathcal{G}_{t}|\geq(1-\alpha)K). We provide a graphical illustration (Fig. 5 in Appendix D) on that if any Byzantine agent is included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t}, its distance to the true gradient ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡0\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}_{0}) is at most 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma, which ensures that its impact on the algorithm is limited. Note that the pairwise computation among the weights of all the agents can be implemented using the Euclidean Distance Matrix Trick [54].

R1 (lines 2-4) is designed in a similar way: R1 ensures that all good agents are highly likely to be included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} by exploiting Lemma 14 (Appendix E) to guarantee that with high probability, all good agents are concentrated in a smaller region. That is, define V≜2​log⁡(2​K/δ)≜𝑉2log2𝐾𝛿V\triangleq 2\operatorname{log}(2K/\delta) and δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), then with probability of ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta, the maximum distance between any two good agents is 𝔗μ≜2​σ​V/Bt≜subscript𝔗𝜇2𝜎𝑉subscript𝐵𝑡\mathfrak{T}_{\mu}\triangleq 2\sigma\sqrt{V/B_{t}}. Having all good agents in a smaller region improves the filtering strategy, because it makes the Byzantine agents less likely to be selected and reduces their impact even if they are selected. Therefore, R1 is applied first such that if R1 fails to include all good agents in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} (line 4) which happens with probability <δabsent𝛿<\delta, R2 is then employed as a backup to ensure that 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} always include all good agents. Therefore, these two filtering rules ensure in any round t𝑡t that (a) gradients from good agents are never filtered out, and that (b) if gradients from Byzantine agents are not filtered out, their impact is limited since their maximum distance to ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡0\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}_{0}) is bounded by 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma.

4 Theoretical results

Here, we firstly put in place a few assumptions required for our theoretical analysis, all of which are common in the literature.

Assumption 3 (On policy derivatives).

Let π𝛉​(a|s)subscript𝜋𝛉conditional𝑎𝑠\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(a|s) be the policy of an agent at state s𝑠s. There exist constants G,M>0𝐺𝑀0G,M>0 s.t. the log-density of the policy function satisfies, for all a∈𝒜𝑎𝒜a\in\mathcal{A} and s∈𝒮𝑠𝒮s\in\mathcal{S}

|∇𝜽logπ𝜽(a|s)|≤G,∥∇𝜽2logπ𝜽(a|s)∥≤M,∀a∈𝒜,∀s∈𝒮\displaystyle|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\operatorname{log}\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(a|s)|\leq G,\qquad\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2}\operatorname{log}\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(a|s)\|\leq M,\qquad\forall a\in\mathcal{A},\forall s\in\mathcal{S}

Assumption 3 provides the basis for the smoothness assumption on the objective function J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) commonly used in non-convex optimization [33, 32] and also appears in  Papini et al. [18], Xu et al. [19]. Specifically, Assumption 3 implies:

Proposition 4 (On function smoothness).

Under Assumption 3, J​(𝛉)𝐽𝛉J(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is L𝐿L-smooth with L≜H​R​(M+H​G2)/(1−γ)≜𝐿𝐻𝑅𝑀𝐻superscript𝐺21𝛾L\triangleq HR(M+HG^{2})/(1-\gamma). Let g​(τ|𝛉)𝑔conditional𝜏𝛉g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}) be the REINFORCE or GPOMDP gradient estimators. Then for all 𝛉,𝛉1,𝛉2∈ℝd𝛉subscript𝛉1subscript𝛉2superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, it holds that

∥g(τ|𝜽)∥≤Cg,∥g(τ∣𝜽1)−g(τ∣𝜽2)∥≤Lg∥𝜽1−𝜽2∥\displaystyle\|g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq C_{g},\qquad\left\|g\left(\tau\mid\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}\right)-g\left(\tau\mid\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\right)\right\|\leq L_{g}\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\right\|

where Lg≜H​M​(R+|Cb|)/(1−γ),Cg≜H​G​(R+|Cb|)/(1−γ)formulae-sequence≜subscript𝐿𝑔𝐻𝑀𝑅subscript𝐶𝑏1𝛾≜subscript𝐶𝑔𝐻𝐺𝑅subscript𝐶𝑏1𝛾L_{g}\triangleq HM(R+|C_{b}|)/(1-\gamma),C_{g}\triangleq HG(R+|C_{b}|)/(1-\gamma) and Cbsubscript𝐶𝑏C_{b} is the baseline reward.

Proposition 4 is important for deriving a fast convergence rate and its proof can be found in Xu et al. [19]. Next, we need an assumption on the variance of the importance weights (Section 3).

Assumption 5 (On variance of the importance weights).

There exists a constant W<∞𝑊W<\infty such that for each policy pairs in Algorithm 1, it holds

Var(ω(τ|𝜽1,𝜽2))≤W,∀𝜽1,𝜽2∈ℝd,τ∼p(⋅|𝜽1)\displaystyle\operatorname{Var}(\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}))\leq W,\qquad\forall\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})

Assumption 5 has also been made by Papini et al. [18], Xu et al. [19]. Now we present the convergence guarantees for our FedPG-BR algorithm:

Theorem 6 (Convergence of FedPG-BR).

Assume uniform initial state distribution across agents, and the gradient estimator is set to be the REINFORCE or GPOMDP estimator. Under Assumptions 2, 3, and 5, if we choose ηt≤12​Ψ​Bt2/3subscript𝜂𝑡12Ψsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑡23\eta_{t}\leq\frac{1}{2\Psi B_{t}^{2/3}}, bt=1subscript𝑏𝑡1b_{t}=1, and Bt=B≥4​Φ​L−2subscript𝐵𝑡𝐵4Φsuperscript𝐿2B_{t}=B\geq 4\Phi L^{-2} where Φ≜Lg+Cg2​Cw≜Φsubscript𝐿𝑔superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑔2subscript𝐶𝑤\Phi\triangleq L_{g}+C_{g}^{2}C_{w}, Ψ≜(L​(Lg+Cg2​Cw))1/3≜Ψsuperscript𝐿subscript𝐿𝑔superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑔2subscript𝐶𝑤13\Psi\triangleq(L(L_{g}+C_{g}^{2}C_{w}))^{1/3}, L,Lg,Cg𝐿subscript𝐿𝑔subscript𝐶𝑔L,L_{g},C_{g} are defined in Proposition 4 and Cwsubscript𝐶𝑤C_{w} is defined in Lemma 9, δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1) such that eδ​Bt2​(1−2​δ)≤2​Kδ≤eBt2superscript𝑒𝛿subscript𝐵𝑡212𝛿2𝐾𝛿superscript𝑒subscript𝐵𝑡2e^{\frac{\delta B_{t}}{2(1-2\delta)}}\leq\frac{2K}{\delta}\leq e^{\frac{B_{t}}{2}} and δ≤15​K​Bt𝛿15𝐾subscript𝐵𝑡\delta\leq\frac{1}{5KB_{t}}, then the output 𝛉~asubscript~𝛉𝑎\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{a} of Algorithm 1 satisfies

𝔼​[‖∇J​(𝜽~a)‖2]≤2​Ψ​[J​(𝜽~∗)−J​(𝜽~0)]T​B1/3+8​σ2(1−α)2​K​B+96​α2​σ2​V(1−α)2​B𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript~𝜽𝑎22Ψdelimited-[]𝐽superscript~𝜽𝐽subscript~𝜽0𝑇superscript𝐵138superscript𝜎2superscript1𝛼2𝐾𝐵96superscript𝛼2superscript𝜎2𝑉superscript1𝛼2𝐵\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{a})\|^{2}]\leq{\frac{2\Psi\left[J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})-J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0})\right]}{TB^{1/3}}}+\frac{8\sigma^{2}}{(1-\alpha)^{2}KB}+\frac{96\alpha^{2}\sigma^{2}V}{(1-\alpha)^{2}B}

where 0≤α<0.50𝛼0.50\leq\alpha<0.5 and 𝛉~∗superscript~𝛉\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*} is a global maximizer of J𝐽J.

This theorem leads to many interesting insights. When K=1,α=0formulae-sequence𝐾1𝛼0K=1,\alpha=0, Theorem 6 reduces to 𝔼​‖∇J​(𝜽~a)‖2≤2​Ψ​[J​(𝜽~∗)−J​(𝜽~0)]/T​B1/3+8​σ2/B𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript~𝜽𝑎22Ψdelimited-[]𝐽superscript~𝜽𝐽subscript~𝜽0𝑇superscript𝐵138superscript𝜎2𝐵\mathbb{E}\|\nabla J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{a})\|^{2}\leq 2\Psi[J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})-J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0})]/TB^{1/3}+8\sigma^{2}/B. The second term here O​(1/B)𝑂1𝐵O(1/B), which also shows up in SVRPG [18, 19], results from the full gradient approximation in Equation (2) in each round. In this case, our theorem implies that 𝔼​‖∇J​(𝜽~a)‖2=O​(Ψ​[J​(𝜽~∗)−J​(𝜽~0)]/T​B1/3)𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript~𝜽𝑎2𝑂Ψdelimited-[]𝐽superscript~𝜽𝐽subscript~𝜽0𝑇superscript𝐵13\mathbb{E}\|\nabla J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{a})\|^{2}=O(\Psi[J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})-J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0})]/TB^{1/3}) which is consistent with SCSG for L𝐿L-smooth non-convex objective functions [35]. Moreover, using 𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)] to denote the expected number of trajectories required by each agent to achieve 𝔼​[‖∇J​(𝜽~a)‖2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript~𝜽𝑎2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{a})\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon, Theorem 6 leads to:

Corollary 7 (Sample complexity of FedPG-BR).

Under the same assumptions as Theorem 6, let ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, we have: (i) 𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]=O​(1ϵ5/3​K2/3+α4/3ϵ5/3)𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53superscript𝐾23superscript𝛼43superscriptitalic-ϵ53\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)]={O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5/3}K^{2/3}}+\frac{\alpha^{4/3}}{\epsilon^{5/3}}); (ii) When α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, we have 𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]=O​(1ϵ5/3​K2/3)𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53superscript𝐾23\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)]={O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5/3}K^{2/3}}); (iii) When K=1𝐾1K\!=\!1, we have 𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]=O​(1ϵ5/3)𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)]={O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5/3}})

We present a straightforward comparison of the sample complexity of related works in Table 1. Both REINFORCE and GPOMDP have a sample complexity of O​(1/ϵ2)𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(1/\epsilon^{2}) since they use stochastic gradient-based optimization. Xu et al. [19] has made a refined analysis of SVRPG to improve its sample complexity from O​(1/ϵ2)𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(1/\epsilon^{2}) [18] to O​(1/ϵ5/3)𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53O(1/\epsilon^{5/3}). Corollary 7 (iii) reveals that the sample complexity of FedPG-BR in the single-agent setup agrees with that of SVRPG derived by Xu et al. [19].

When K>1𝐾1K>1, α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, Corollary 7 (ii) implies that the total number of trajectories required by each agent is upper-bounded by O​(1/(ϵ5/3​K2/3))𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53superscript𝐾23O(1/(\epsilon^{5/3}K^{2/3})). This result gives us the theoretical grounds to encourage more agents to participate in the federation, since the number of trajectories each agent needs to sample decays at a rate of O​(1/K2/3)𝑂1superscript𝐾23O(1/K^{2/3}). This guaranteed improvement in sample efficiency is highly desirable in practical systems with a large number of agents.

Next, for a more realistic system where an α𝛼\alpha-fraction (α>0)𝛼0(\alpha>0) of the agents are Byzantine agents, Corollary 7 (i) assures us that the total number of trajectories required by each agent will be increased by only an additive term of O​(α4/3/ϵ5/3)𝑂superscript𝛼43superscriptitalic-ϵ53O(\alpha^{4/3}/\epsilon^{5/3}). This term is unavoidable due to the presence of Byzantine agents in FRL systems. However, the bound implies that the impact of Byzantine agents on the overall convergence is limited, which aligns with the discussions on our Byzantine filtering strategy (Section 3.3), and will be empirically verified in our experiments. Moreover, the impact of Byzantine agents on the convergence vanishes when α→0→𝛼0\alpha\rightarrow 0. That is, when the system is ideal (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0), our Byzantine filtering step induces no effect on the convergence.

5 Experiments

We evaluate the empirical performances of FedPG-BR with and without Byzantine agents on different RL benchmarks, including CartPole balancing [55], LunarLander, and the 3D continuous locomotion control task of Half-Cheetah [56]. In all experiments, we measure the performance online such that in each iteration, we evaluate the current policy of the server by using it to independently interact with the test MDP for 10 trajectories and reporting the mean returns. Each experiment is independently repeated 10 times with different random seeds and policy initializations, both of which are shared among all algorithms for fair comparisons. The results are averaged over the 10 independent runs with 90%percent9090\% bootstrap confidence intervals. Due to space constraints, some experimental details are deferred to Appendix F.

Performances in ideal systems with α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. We firstly evaluate the performances of FedPG-BR in ideal systems with α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, i.e., no Byzantine agents. We compare FedPG-BR (K=1,3,10𝐾1310K\!=\!1,3,10) with vanilla policy gradient using GPOMDP333Since GPOMDP has been repeatedly found to be comparable to or better than REINFORCE [18, 19]. and SVRPG. The results in all three tasks are plotted in Fig. 2. The figures show that FedPG-BR (K=1𝐾1K\!=\!1) and SVRPG perform comparably, both outperforming GPOMDP. This aligns with the results in Table 1 showing that FedPG-BR (K=1𝐾1K\!=\!1) and SVRPG share the same sample complexity, and both are provably more sample-efficient than GPOMDP. Moreover, the performance of FedPG-BR is improved significantly with the federated of only K=3𝐾3K=3 agents, and improved even further when K=10𝐾10K=10. This corroborates our theoretical insights implying that the federation of more agents (i.e., larger K𝐾K) improves the sample efficiency of FedPG-BR (Section 4), and verifies the practical performance benefit offered by the participation of more agents.

Performances in practical systems with α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. Next, we investigate the impact of Byzantine agents (i.e., random failures or adversarial attacks) on the sample efficiency, which is critical for the practical deployment of FRL algorithms. In this experiment, we use K=10𝐾10K=10 agents among which 333 are Byzantine agents, and we simulate different types of Byzantine failures: (a) Random Noise (RN): each Byzantine agent sends a random vector to the server; (b) Random Action (RA): every Byzantine agent ignores the policy from the server and takes actions randomly, which is used to simulate random system failures (e.g., hardware failures) and results in false gradient computations since the trajectories are no longer sampled according to the policy; (c) Sign Filliping (SF): each Byzantine agent computes the correct gradient but sends the scaled negative gradient (multiplied by −2.52.5-2.5),which is used to simulate adversarial attacks aiming to manipulate the direction of policy update at the server.

For comparison, we have adapted both GPOMDP and SVRPG to the FRL setting (pseudocode is provided in Appendix A.3). Fig. 3 shows the results using the HalfCheetah task. We have also included the performances of GPOMDP, SVRPG and FedPG-BR in the single-agent settting (K=1𝐾1K\!=\!1) as dotted-line (mean value of 10 independent runs) for reference. The figures show that for both GPOMDP and SVRPG, the 3 Byzantine agents cause the performance of their federated versions to be worse than that in the single-agent setting. Particularly, RA agents (middle figure) render GPOMDP and SVRPG unlearnable, i.e., unable to converge at all. In contrast, our FedPG-BR is robust against all three types of Byzantine failures. That is, FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K\!=\!10\ B\!=\!3) with 3 Byzantine agents still significantly outperforms the single-agent setting, and more importantly, performs comparably to FedPG-BR (K=10𝐾10K\!=\!10) with 10 good agents. This is because our Byzantine filtering strategy can effectively filter out those Byzantine agents. These results demonstrate that even in practical systems which are subject to random failures or adversarial attacks, FedPG-BR is still able to deliver superior performances. This provides an assurance on the reliability of our FedPG-BR algorithm to promote its practical deployment, and significantly improves the practicality of FRL. The results for the CartPole and LunarLander tasks, which yield the same insights as discussed here, can be found in Appendix G.

Performance of FedPG-BR against FedPG attack. We have discussed (Section 3.3) and shown through theoretical analysis (Section 4) that even when our Byzantine filtering strategy fails, the impact of the Byzantine agents on the performance of our algorithm is still limited. Here we verify this empirically. To this end, we design a new type of Byzantine agents who have perfect knowledge about our Byzantine filtering strategy, and call it FedPG attacker. The goal of FedPG attackers are to collude with each other to attack our algorithm without being filtered out. To achieve this, FedPG attackers firstly estimate ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) using the mean of their gradients μ¯tsubscript¯𝜇𝑡\bar{\mu}_{t}, and estimate σ𝜎\sigma by calculating the maximum Euclidean distance between the gradients of any two FedPG attackers as 2​σ¯2¯𝜎2\bar{\sigma}. Next, all FedPG attackers send the vector μ¯t+3​σ¯subscript¯𝜇𝑡3¯𝜎\bar{\mu}_{t}+3\bar{\sigma} to the server. Recall we have discussed in Section 3.3 that if a Byzantine agent is not filtered out, its distance to the true gradient ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡0\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}_{0}) is at most 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma. Therefore, if μ¯tsubscript¯𝜇𝑡\bar{\mu}_{t} and σ¯¯𝜎\bar{\sigma} are estimated accurately, the vectors from the FedPG attackers can exert negative impact on the convergence while still evading our Byzantine filtering.

We again use K=10𝐾10K=10 agents, among which 3 are FedPG attackers. The results (Fig. 4) show that in all three tasks, even against such stong attackers with perfect knowledge of our Byzantine filtering strategy, FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K\!=\!10\ B\!=\!3) still manages to significantly outperform FedPG-BR (K=1𝐾1K\!=\!1) in the single-agent setting. Moreover, the performance of FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K\!=\!10\ B\!=\!3) is only marginally worsened compared with FedPG-BR (K=10𝐾10K\!=\!10) with 10 good agents. This corroborates our theoretical analysis showing that although we place no assumption on the gradients sent by the Byzantine agents, they only contribute an additive term of O​(α4/3/ϵ5/3)𝑂superscript𝛼43superscriptitalic-ϵ53O(\alpha^{4/3}/\epsilon^{5/3}) to the sample complexity (Section 4). These results demonstrate the empirical robustness of FedPG-BR even against strong attackers, hence further highlighting its practical reliability.

6 Conclusion and future work

Federation is promising in boosting the sample efficiency of RL agents, without sharing their trajectories. Due to the high sampling cost of RL, the design of FRL systems appeals for theoretical guarantee on its convergence which is, however, vulnerable to failures and attacks in practical setup, as demonstrated. This paper provides the theoretical ground to study the sample efficiency of FRL with respect to the number of participating agents, while accounting for faulty agents. We verify the empirical efficacy of the proposed FRL framework in systems with and without different types of faulty agents on various RL benchmarks.

Variance control is the key to exploiting Assumption 2 on the bounded variance of PG estimators in our filter design. As a result, our framework is restricted to the variance-reduced policy gradient methods. Intuitively, it is worth studying the fault-tolerant federation of other policy optimization methods. Another limitation of this work is that agents are assumed to be homogeneous, while in many real-world scenarios, RL agents are heterogeneous. Therefore, it would be interesting to explore the possibility of heterogeneity of agents in fault-tolerant FRL in future works. Moreover, another interesting future work is to apply our Byzantine filtering strategy to other federated sequential decision-making problems such as federated bandit [57, 58, 59] and federated/collaborative Bayesian optimization [60, 61, 62], as well as other settings of collaborative multi-party ML [63, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 71, 72, 73, 74, 75], to equip them with theoretically guaranteed fault tolerance.

Appendix A More on the background

A.1 SVRG and SCSG

Here we provide the pseudocode for SVRG (Algorithm 2) and SCSG (Algorithm 3) seen in Lei et al. [35]. The idea of SVRG (Algorithm 2) is to reuses past full gradient computations (line 3) to reduce the variance of the current stochastic gradient estimate (line 7) before the parameter update (line 8). Note that N=1𝑁1N=1 corresponds to a GD step (i.e., vk−1(j)←gj←superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑘1𝑗subscript𝑔𝑗v_{k-1}^{(j)}\leftarrow g_{j} in line 7). For N>1𝑁1N>1, vk−1(j)superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑘1𝑗v_{k-1}^{(j)} is the corrected gradient in SVRG and is an unbiased estimate of the true gradient ∇J​(𝜽)∇𝐽𝜽\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}). SVRG achieves linear convergence O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/T) using the semi-stochastic gradient.

More recently, Stochastically Controlled Stochastic Gradient (SCSG) has been proposed [34], to further reduce the computational cost of SVRG. The key difference is that SCSG (Algorithm 3) considers a sequence of time-varying batch sizes (Btsubscript𝐵𝑡B_{t} and btsubscript𝑏𝑡b_{t}) and employs geometric sampling to generate the number of parameter update steps Ntsubscript𝑁𝑡N_{t} in each iteration (line 6), instead of fixing the batch sizes and the number of updates as done in SVRG. Particularly when finding an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate solution (Definition 1) for optimizing smooth non-convex objectives, Lei et al. [35] proves that SCSG is never worse than SVRG in convergence rate and significantly outperforms SVRG when the required ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small.

As a member of the SVRG-like algorithms, SCSG enjoys the same convergence rate of SVRG while being computationally cheaper than SVRG for tasks with small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon requirements [34], which is highly desired in RL, hence the motivation of FedPG-BR to adapt SCSG.

A.2 Gradient estimator

Use g​(τ|𝜽)𝑔conditional𝜏𝜽g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}) to denote the unbiased estimator to the true gradient J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}). The common gradient estimators are the REINFORCE and the GPOMDP estimators, which are considered as baseline estimators in [18] and [19]. The REINFORCE [39]:

g​(τ|𝜽)=[∑h=0H−1∇𝜽log⁡π𝜽​(ah∣sh)]​[∑h=0H−1γh​ℛ​(sh,ah)−Cb]𝑔conditional𝜏𝜽delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptℎ0𝐻1subscript∇𝜽subscript𝜋𝜽conditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptℎ0𝐻1superscript𝛾ℎℛsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝐶𝑏\displaystyle g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left[\sum_{h=0}^{H-1}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\log\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(a_{h}\mid s_{h})\right]\left[\sum_{h=0}^{H-1}\gamma^{h}\mathcal{R}(s_{h},a_{h})-C_{b}\right]

And the GPOMDP [40]

g​(τ|𝜽)=∑h=0H−1[∑t=0h∇𝜽log⁡π𝜽​(at∣st)]​(γh​r​(sh,ah)−Cbh)𝑔conditional𝜏𝜽superscriptsubscriptℎ0𝐻1delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡0ℎsubscript∇𝜽subscript𝜋𝜽conditionalsubscript𝑎𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡superscript𝛾ℎ𝑟subscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝐶subscript𝑏ℎ\displaystyle g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{h=0}^{H-1}\left[\sum_{t=0}^{h}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\log\pi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(a_{t}\mid s_{t})\right](\gamma^{h}r(s_{h},a_{h})-C_{b_{h}})

where Cbsubscript𝐶𝑏C_{b} and Cbhsubscript𝐶subscript𝑏ℎC_{b_{h}} are the corresponding baselines. Under Assumption 3, whether we use the REINFORCE or the GPOMDP estimator, Proposition 4 holds [18, 19].

A.3 Federated GPOMDP and SVRPG

Closely following the problem setting of FedPG-BR, we adapt both GPOMDP and SVRPG to the FRL setting. The pseudocode is shown in Algorithm 4 and Algorithm 5.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 6

In our proof, we follow the suggestion from Lei et al. [35] to set bt=1subscript𝑏𝑡1b_{t}=1 to derive better theoretical results. Refer to Section F in this appendix for the value of btsubscript𝑏𝑡b_{t} used in our experiments.

Proof.

From the L-smoothness of the objective function J​(𝜽)𝐽𝜽J(\boldsymbol{\theta}), we have

Appendix C Proof of Corollary 7

Proof.

Recall Ψ=(L​(Lg+Cg2​Cw))1/3Ψsuperscript𝐿subscript𝐿𝑔superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑔2subscript𝐶𝑤13\Psi=(L(L_{g}+C_{g}^{2}C_{w}))^{1/3}. From Theorem 6, we have

𝔼​‖∇J​(𝜽~a)‖2≤2​Ψ​𝔼​[J​(𝜽~∗)−J​(𝜽~0)]T​B1/3⏟T=O​(1ϵ​B1/3)+8​σ2(1−α)2​K​B⏟BK=O​(1ϵ​K)+96​α2​σ2​V(1−α)2​B⏟Bα=O​(α2ϵ)𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript~𝜽𝑎2subscript⏟2Ψ𝔼delimited-[]𝐽superscript~𝜽𝐽subscript~𝜽0𝑇superscript𝐵13𝑇𝑂1italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵13subscript⏟8superscript𝜎2superscript1𝛼2𝐾𝐵subscript𝐵𝐾𝑂1italic-ϵ𝐾subscript⏟96superscript𝛼2superscript𝜎2𝑉superscript1𝛼2𝐵subscript𝐵𝛼𝑂superscript𝛼2italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\nabla J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{a})\|^{2}\leq\underbrace{\frac{2\Psi\mathbb{E}\left[J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})-J(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0})\right]}{TB^{1/3}}}_{T=O(\frac{1}{\epsilon B^{1/3}})}+\underbrace{\frac{8\sigma^{2}}{(1-\alpha)^{2}KB}}_{B_{K}=O(\frac{1}{\epsilon K})}+\underbrace{\frac{96\alpha^{2}\sigma^{2}V}{(1-\alpha)^{2}B}}_{B_{\alpha}=O(\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\epsilon})}

To guarantee that the output of Algorithm 1 is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate, i.e., 𝔼​‖∇J​(𝜽~a)‖2≤ϵ𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscriptbold-~𝜽𝑎2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\|\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\tilde{\theta}}_{a})\|^{2}\leq\epsilon, we need the number of rounds T𝑇T and the batch size B𝐵B to meet the following:

(i)​T=O​(1ϵ​B1/3),(ii)​BK=O​(1ϵ​K)​, and (iii)​Bα=O​(α2ϵ)formulae-sequence(i)𝑇𝑂1italic-ϵsuperscript𝐵13(ii)subscript𝐵𝐾𝑂1italic-ϵ𝐾, and (iii)subscript𝐵𝛼𝑂superscript𝛼2italic-ϵ\displaystyle\text{(i)}T=O(\frac{1}{\epsilon B^{1/3}}),\text{(ii)}B_{K}=O(\frac{1}{\epsilon K})\text{, and (iii)}B_{\alpha}=O(\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\epsilon})

By union bound and using 𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)] to denote the total number of trajectories required by each agent to sample, the above implies that

𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)] ≤T​BK+T​Bαabsent𝑇subscript𝐵𝐾𝑇subscript𝐵𝛼\displaystyle\leq TB_{K}+TB_{\alpha}
≤O​(1ϵ5/3​K2/3+α4/3ϵ5/3)absent𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53superscript𝐾23superscript𝛼43superscriptitalic-ϵ53\displaystyle\leq O(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5/3}K^{2/3}}+\frac{\alpha^{4/3}}{\epsilon^{5/3}})

in order to obtain an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate policy, which completes the proof for Corollary 7 (i). Note that the total number of trajectories generated across the whole FRL system, denoted by 𝔼​[T​r​a​jt​o​t​a​l​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎subscript𝑗𝑡𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[Traj_{total}(\epsilon)] is thus bounded by:

𝔼​[T​r​a​jt​o​t​a​l​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎subscript𝑗𝑡𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[Traj_{total}(\epsilon)] ≤O​(K1/3ϵ5/3+K​α4/3ϵ5/3)absent𝑂superscript𝐾13superscriptitalic-ϵ53𝐾superscript𝛼43superscriptitalic-ϵ53\displaystyle\leq O(\frac{K^{1/3}}{\epsilon^{5/3}}+\frac{K\alpha^{4/3}}{\epsilon^{5/3}})

Now for an ideal system where α=0𝛼0\alpha=0:

𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)] ≤O​(1ϵ5/3​K2/3)absent𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53superscript𝐾23\displaystyle\leq O(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5/3}K^{2/3}})
𝔼​[T​r​a​jt​o​t​a​l​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎subscript𝑗𝑡𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[Traj_{total}(\epsilon)] ≤O​(K1/3ϵ5/3)absent𝑂superscript𝐾13superscriptitalic-ϵ53\displaystyle\leq O(\frac{K^{1/3}}{\epsilon^{5/3}})

which completes the proof for Corollary 7 (ii). Moreover, when K=1𝐾1K=1, the number of trajectories required by the agent using FedPG-BR is

𝔼​[T​r​a​j​(ϵ)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑗italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[Traj(\epsilon)] ≤O​(1ϵ5/3)absent𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ53\displaystyle\leq O(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5/3}})

which is Corollary 7 (iii) and is coherent with the recent analysis of SVRPG [19]. ∎

Appendix D More on the Byzantine Filtering Step

In this section, we continue our discussion on our Byzantine Filtering Step in Section 3.3. We include the pseudocode for the subroutine FedPG-Aggregate below for ease of reference:

As discussed in Section 3.3, R2 (line 8 in Algorithm 1.1) ensures that 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} always include all good agents and for any Byzantine agents being included, their impact on the convergence of Algorithm 1 is limited since their maximum distance to ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) is bounded by 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma. Here we give proofs for the claims.

Claim D.1.

Under Assumption 2 and ∀α<0.5for-all𝛼0.5\forall\alpha<0.5, the filtering rule R2 in Algorithm 1.1 ensures that, in any round t𝑡t, all gradient estimates sent from non-Byzantine agents are included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t}, i.e., |𝒢t|≥(1−α)​Ksubscript𝒢𝑡1𝛼𝐾|\mathcal{G}_{t}|\geq(1-\alpha)K.

Proof.

First, from Assumption 2:

‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖≤σ,∀k∈𝒢formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝜎for-all𝑘𝒢\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|\leq\sigma,\forall k\in\mathcal{G}

it implies that ‖μt(k1)−μt(k2)‖≤2​σ,∀k1,k2∈𝒢formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑘22𝜎for-allsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2𝒢\|\mu_{t}^{(k_{1})}-\mu_{t}^{(k_{2})}\|\leq 2\sigma,\forall k_{1},k_{2}\in\mathcal{G}. So, for any value of the vector median [46] in S2 ={μt(k)}absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘=\{\mu_{t}^{(k)}\} (defined in line 6):

‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖≤3​σ,∀μt(k)∈S2formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡3𝜎for-allsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘S2\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|\leq 3\sigma,\forall\mu_{t}^{(k)}\in\text{S2}

An intuitive illustration is provided in Fig. 5. Next, consider the worst case where all values sent by the K𝐾K agents are included in S2: for all (1−α)​K1𝛼𝐾(1-\alpha)K good agents, they send the same value μt(k)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘\mu_{t}^{(k)}, s.t., ‖∇J​(𝜽0t)−μt(k)‖=σ,∀k∈𝒢formulae-sequencenorm∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘𝜎for-all𝑘𝒢\|\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})-\mu_{t}^{(k)}\|=\sigma,\forall k\in\mathcal{G}; and for all α​K𝛼𝐾\alpha K Byzantine agents, they send the same value μt(k′)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡superscript𝑘′\mu_{t}^{(k^{\prime})} s.t., ‖∇J​(𝜽0t)−μt(k′)‖=3​σ,∀k′∈S​2∖𝒢formulae-sequencenorm∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡superscript𝑘′3𝜎for-allsuperscript𝑘′𝑆2𝒢\|\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})-\mu_{t}^{(k^{\prime})}\|=3\sigma,\forall k^{\prime}\in S2\setminus\mathcal{G}. Then the mean of values in S2 satisfies:

‖μtmean−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mean∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mean}}-\nabla J({\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}})\| =(1−α)​K⋅σ+α​K⋅3​σKabsent⋅1𝛼𝐾𝜎⋅𝛼𝐾3𝜎𝐾\displaystyle=\frac{(1-\alpha)K\cdot\sigma+\alpha K\cdot 3\sigma}{K}
=(1−α)​σ+3​α​σabsent1𝛼𝜎3𝛼𝜎\displaystyle=(1-\alpha)\sigma+3\alpha\sigma
=σ+2​α​σabsent𝜎2𝛼𝜎\displaystyle=\sigma+2\alpha\sigma
<2​σabsent2𝜎\displaystyle<2\sigma

where the last inequality holds for α<0.5𝛼0.5\alpha<0.5 which is our assumption. Then the value μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}} of Algorithm 1 will be set to any μt(k)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘\mu_{t}^{(k)} from S2, of which is the closet to μtmeansuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mean\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mean}}.

The selection of μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}} implies ‖μtmom−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖≤σnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝜎\|\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|\leq\sigma. Therefore, by constructing a region of 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} that is centred at μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}} and 2​σ2𝜎2\sigma in radius (line 8), 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} can cover all estimates from non-Byzantine agents and hence ensure |𝒢t|≥(1−α)​Ksubscript𝒢𝑡1𝛼𝐾|\mathcal{G}_{t}|\geq(1-\alpha)K. ∎

Claim D.2.

Under Assumption 2 and α<0.5𝛼0.5\alpha<0.5, the filtering rule R2 in Algorithm 1.1 ensures that, in any round t𝑡t, ‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝛉0t)‖≤3​σ,∀k∈𝒢tformulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝛉0𝑡3𝜎for-all𝑘subscript𝒢𝑡\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|\leq 3\sigma,\forall k\in\mathcal{G}_{t}.

Proof.

This lemma is a straightforward result following the proof of Claim D.1. ∎

Remark.

Claim D.2 implies that, in any round t𝑡t, if an estimate sent from Byzantine agent is included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t}, then its impact on the convergence of Algorithm 1 is limited since its distance to ∇J​(𝛉0t)∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝛉0𝑡\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) is bounded by 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma. Fig. 5 provides an intuitive illustration for this claim.

As discussed above, R2 ensures that all good agents are included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t}, i.e., a region in which all good agents are concentrated. R1 (lines 2-4) is designed in a similar way and aims to improve the practical performance of FedPG-BR by exploiting Lemma 14: all good agents are highly likely to be concentrated in a much smaller region.

Claim D.3.

Define V≜2​log⁡(2​K/δ)≜𝑉2log2𝐾𝛿V\triangleq 2\operatorname{log}(2K/\delta) and δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), the filtering R1 in Algorithm 1 ensure

‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖≤σ​VBt,∀k∈𝒢formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝜎𝑉subscript𝐵𝑡for-all𝑘𝒢\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|\leq\sigma\sqrt{\frac{V}{B_{t}}},\forall k\in\mathcal{G}

with probability of at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta.

Proof.

From Assumption 2, ‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖≤σ,∀k∈𝒢formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝜎for-all𝑘𝒢\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|\leq\sigma,\forall k\in\mathcal{G}. We have

‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽0t)‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\| =∥1Bt∑i=1Btg(τt,i(k)|𝜽0t)−∇J(𝜽0t)∥\displaystyle=\left\|\frac{1}{B_{t}}\sum_{i=1}^{B_{t}}g(\tau_{t,i}^{(k)}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\right\|
=1Bt​∥∑i=1Btg(τt,i(k)|𝜽0t)−∇J(𝜽0t)∥2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{B_{t}}\sqrt{\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{B_{t}}g(\tau_{t,i}^{(k)}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\right\|^{2}} (12)

Consider Xi≜g​(τt,i(k))−∇J​(𝜽0t)≜subscript𝑋𝑖𝑔superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑖𝑘∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡X_{i}\triangleq g(\tau_{t,i}^{(k)})-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) and apply Lemma 14 on (12), we have

Pr⁡[‖∑i=1BtXi‖2≤2​log⁡(2δ)​σ2​Bt]≥1−δPrsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐵𝑡subscript𝑋𝑖22log2𝛿superscript𝜎2subscript𝐵𝑡1𝛿\displaystyle\Pr\left[\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{B_{t}}X_{i}\right\|^{2}\leq 2\operatorname{log}(\frac{2}{\delta})\sigma^{2}B_{t}\right]\geq 1-\delta
Pr⁡[1Bt​‖∑i=1BtXi‖2≤1Bt​2​log⁡(2δ)​σ2​Bt]≥1−δPr1subscript𝐵𝑡superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐵𝑡subscript𝑋𝑖21subscript𝐵𝑡2log2𝛿superscript𝜎2subscript𝐵𝑡1𝛿\displaystyle\Pr\left[\frac{1}{B_{t}}\sqrt{\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{B_{t}}X_{i}\right\|^{2}}\leq\frac{1}{B_{t}}\sqrt{2\operatorname{log}(\frac{2}{\delta})\sigma^{2}B_{t}}\right]\geq 1-\delta

With V≜2​log⁡(2​K/δ)≜𝑉2log2𝐾𝛿V\triangleq 2\operatorname{log}(2K/\delta) and δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), the above inequality yields the Claim. ∎

Therefore, the first filtering R1 (lines 2-4) of FedPG-BR constructs a region of 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} centred at μtmomsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}} with radius of 2​σ​VBt2𝜎𝑉subscript𝐵𝑡2\sigma\sqrt{\frac{V}{B_{t}}}, which ensures in any round t𝑡t that, with probability ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta, (a) all good agents are included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t}, and (b) if gradients from Byzantine agents are included in 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t}, their impact is limited since their maximum distance to ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}) is bounded by 3​σ​VBt3𝜎𝑉subscript𝐵𝑡3\sigma\sqrt{\frac{V}{B_{t}}} (The proof is similar to that of Claim D.2). Compared to R2, R1 can construct a smaller region that the server believes contains all good agents. If any Byzantine agent is included, their impact is also smaller, with probability of at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta. Therefore, R1 is applied first such that if R1 fails (line 5) which happens with probability <δabsent𝛿<\delta, R2 is then employed as a backup to ensure that 𝒢tsubscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}_{t} always includes all good agents.

Appendix E Useful technical lemmas

Lemma 8 (Unbiaseness of importance sampling).
𝔼τ∼p(⋅∣𝜽n)​[ω​(τ|𝜽n,𝜽0)​g​(τ|𝜽0)]\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p\left(\cdot\mid\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}\right)}[\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})] =𝔼τ∼p(⋅|𝜽0)​[g​(τ|𝜽0)]\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}[g(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})]
=∇J​(𝜽0)absent∇𝐽subscript𝜽0\displaystyle=\nabla J({\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}})
Proof.

Drop t𝑡t from notation and use τnsubscript𝜏𝑛\tau_{n} to denote trajectories sampled from 𝜽nsubscript𝜽𝑛\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n} at step n𝑛n. From the definition of gradient estimation, we have

g​(τn|𝜽0)𝑔conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑛subscript𝜽0\displaystyle g(\tau_{n}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}) =𝔼τ∼p(⋅|𝜽n)​[∇𝜽0p​(𝜽0)​r​(τ)]\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})}[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}p(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})r(\tau)]
=∫p(⋅|𝜽n)∇𝜽0p(𝜽0)r(τ)dτ\displaystyle=\int p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}p(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})r(\tau)d\tau
=∫p(⋅|𝜽0)p(⋅|𝜽0)p(⋅|𝜽n)∇𝜽0p(𝜽0)r(τ)dτ\displaystyle=\int\frac{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}p(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})r(\tau)d\tau
=∫p(⋅|𝜽0)p(⋅|𝜽n)p(⋅|𝜽0)∇𝜽0p(𝜽0)r(τ)dτ\displaystyle=\int p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})\frac{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})}{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}p(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})r(\tau)d\tau
=𝔼τ∼p(⋅|𝜽0)​[p(⋅|𝜽n)p(⋅|𝜽0)​∇𝜽0p​(𝜽0)​r​(τ)]\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\tau\sim p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}\left[\frac{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})}{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}p(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})r(\tau)\right]
=p(⋅|𝜽n)p(⋅|𝜽0)​g​(τ0|𝜽0)\displaystyle=\frac{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})}{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}g(\tau_{0}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})

Then,

ω​(τ|𝜽n,𝜽0)​g​(τn|𝜽0)𝜔conditional𝜏subscript𝜽𝑛subscript𝜽0𝑔conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑛subscript𝜽0\displaystyle\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})g(\tau_{n}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}) =p(⋅|𝜽0)p(⋅|𝜽n)​g​(τn|𝜽0)\displaystyle=\frac{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})}{p(\cdot|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n})}g(\tau_{n}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})
=g​(τ0|𝜽0)absent𝑔conditionalsubscript𝜏0subscript𝜽0\displaystyle=g(\tau_{0}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0})

which gives the lemma. ∎

Lemma 9 (Adapted from [19]).

Let ω​(τ|𝛉1,𝛉2)=p​(τ|𝛉1)/p​(τ|𝛉2)𝜔conditional𝜏subscript𝛉1subscript𝛉2𝑝conditional𝜏subscript𝛉1𝑝conditional𝜏subscript𝛉2\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})=p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})/p(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}), under Assumptions 3 and 5, it holds that

V​a​r​(ω​(τ|𝜽1,𝜽2))≤Cw​‖𝜽1−𝜽2‖2𝑉𝑎𝑟𝜔conditional𝜏subscript𝜽1subscript𝜽2subscript𝐶𝑤superscriptnormsubscript𝜽1subscript𝜽22\displaystyle Var(\omega(\tau|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}))\leq C_{w}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\|^{2}

where Cw=H​(2​H​G2+M)​(W+1)subscript𝐶𝑤𝐻2𝐻superscript𝐺2𝑀𝑊1C_{w}=H(2HG^{2}+M)(W+1). Furthermore, we have

𝔼τntsubscript𝔼superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\tau_{n}^{t}} ∥1−ω(τnt|𝜽nt,𝜽0t)∥2\displaystyle\|1-\omega(\tau_{n}^{t}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t})\|^{2}
=V​a​r𝜽nt,𝜽0t​(ω​(τnt|𝜽nt,𝜽0t))absent𝑉𝑎subscript𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡𝜔conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽0𝑡\displaystyle=Var_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}}(\omega(\tau_{n}^{t}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}^{t}))
≤Cw​‖𝜽nt−𝜽0t‖2absentsubscript𝐶𝑤superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡02\displaystyle\leq C_{w}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}^{t}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}_{0}\|^{2}
Proof.

The proof can be found in Xu et al. [19]. ∎

Lemma 10.

Taking expectation with respect to the whole past yields the lemma. ∎

If we choose δ𝛿\delta and Btsubscript𝐵𝑡B_{t} in Algorithm 1 such that:
(i) eδ​Bt2​(1−2​δ)≤2​Kδ≤eBt2superscripte𝛿subscript𝐵𝑡212𝛿2𝐾𝛿superscriptesubscript𝐵𝑡2\mathrm{e}^{\frac{\delta B_{t}}{2(1-2\delta)}}\leq\frac{2K}{\delta}\leq\mathrm{e}^{\frac{B_{t}}{2}}

𝔼​‖et‖2≤4​σ2(1−α)2​K​Bt+48​α2​σ2​V(1−α)2​Bt𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑒𝑡24superscript𝜎2superscript1𝛼2𝐾subscript𝐵𝑡48superscript𝛼2superscript𝜎2𝑉superscript1𝛼2subscript𝐵𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\|e_{t}\right\|^{2}\leq\frac{4\sigma^{2}}{(1-\alpha)^{2}KB_{t}}+\frac{48\alpha^{2}\sigma^{2}V}{(1-\alpha)^{2}B_{t}}
Proof.

The proof of this lemma is similar to that of Lemma 7 of Khanduri et al. [48]. The key difference lays on the base conditions used to define the probabilistic events.

In FedPG-BR, the following refined conditions (results of Claims D.1 and D.2) are used,

‖μtmom−∇J​(𝜽)‖≤σ,‖μt(k)−μtmom‖≤2​σ,‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽)‖≤3​σ,∀k∈𝒢tformulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom∇𝐽𝜽𝜎formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡mom2𝜎formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽𝜽3𝜎for-all𝑘subscript𝒢𝑡\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq\sigma,\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{mom}}\|\leq 2\sigma,\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq 3\sigma,\forall k\in\mathcal{G}_{t}

whereas Khanduri et al. [48] needs the following:

‖μtmed−∇J​(𝜽)‖≤3​σ,‖μt(k)−μtmed‖≤4​σ,‖μt(k)−∇J​(𝜽)‖≤7​σ,∀k∈𝒢tformulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡med∇𝐽𝜽3𝜎formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡med4𝜎formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑡𝑘∇𝐽𝜽7𝜎for-all𝑘subscript𝒢𝑡\displaystyle\|\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{med}}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq 3\sigma,\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\mu_{t}^{\operatorname{med}}\|\leq 4\sigma,\|\mu_{t}^{(k)}-\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq 7\sigma,\forall k\in\mathcal{G}_{t}

The detailed proof of Lemma 15 can be obtained following the derivation of Lemma 7 of Khanduri et al. [48] by modifying the base conditions. ∎

Lemma 17 (Young’s inequality (Peter-Paul inequality)).

For all real numbers a𝑎a and b𝑏b and all β>0𝛽0\beta>0, we have

a​b≤a22​β+β​b22𝑎𝑏superscript𝑎22𝛽𝛽superscript𝑏22\displaystyle ab\leq\frac{a^{2}}{2\beta}+\frac{\beta b^{2}}{2}

Appendix F Experimental details

F.1 Hyperparameters

We follow the setups of SVRPG [18] to parameterize the policies using neural networks. For all the algorithms under comparison in the experiments (Section 5), Adam[77] is used as the gradient optimizer. The 10 random seeds are [0−9]delimited-[]09[0\!-\!9]. All other hyperparameters used in all the experiments are reported in Table 2.

F.2 Computing Infrastructure

All experiments are conducted on a computing server without GPUs. The server is equipped with 14 cores (28 threads) Intel(R) Core(TM) i9-10940X CPU @ 3.30GHz and 64G memory. The average runtime for each run of FedPG-BR (K=10 B=3) is 2.5 hours for the CartPole task, 4 hours for the HalfCheetah task, and 12 hours for the LunarLander task.

Appendix G Additional experiments

G.1 Performance of FedPG-BR in practical systems with α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 for the CartPole and the LunarLander tasks

The results for the CartPole and the LunarLander tasks which yield the same insights as discussed in experiments (Section 5) are plotted in Figure 6 and Figure 7. As discussed earlier, for both GPOMDP and SVRPG, the federation of more agents in practical systems which are subject to the presence of Byzantine agents, i.e., random failures or adversarial attacks, causes the performance of their federation to be worse than that in the single-agent setting. In particular, RA agents (middle figure) and SF agents (right figure) render GPOMDP and SVRPG unlearnable, i.e., unable to converge at all. This is in contrast to the performance of FedPG-BR. That is, FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K=10B=3) is able to deliver superior performances even in the presence of Byzantine agents for all three tasks: CartPole (Figure 6), LunarLander (Figure 7), and HalfCheetah (Figure 3 in Section 5). This provides an assurance on the reliability of our FedPG-BR algorithm to promote its practical deployment, and significantly improves the practicality of FRL.

G.2 Performance of FedPG-BR against the Variance Attack

We have discussed in Section 3.2 where the high variance in PG estimation renders the FRL system vunlnerable to variance-based attacks such as the Variance Attack (VA) proposed by Baruch et al. [47]. The VA attackers collude together to estimate the population mean and the standard-deviation of gradients at each round, and move the mean by the largest value such that their values are still within the population variance. Intuitively, this non-omniscient attack works by exploiting the high variance in gradient estimation of the population and crafting values that contribute most to the population variance, hence gradually shifting the population mean. According to Cao et al. [20], existing defenses will fail to remove those non-omniscient attackers and the convergence will be significantly worsened if the population variance is large enough.

We are thus motivated to look for solutions that theoretically reduce the variance in policy gradient estimation. Inspired by the variance-reduced policy gradient works [e.g., 18, 19], we adapt the SCSG optimization [35] to our federated policy gradient framework for a refined control over the estimation variance. Through our adaptation, we are able to control the variance by the semi-stochastic gradient (line 11 in Algorithm 1), hence resulting in the fault-tolerant FRL system that can defend the VA attackers. Each plot in Figure 8 shows the experiment for each of the three tasks correspondingly, where 3 Byzantine agents are implemented as the VA attackers [20] (zm​a​xsuperscript𝑧𝑚𝑎𝑥z^{max} is 0.180.180.18 in our setup). We again include the corresponding single-agent performance (K=1𝐾1K=1) and the federation of 10 good agents (K=10𝐾10K=10) in the plots for reference. The results show that in all three tasks, FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K=10B=3) still manages to significantly outperform FedPG-BR (K=1𝐾1K=1) in the single-agent setting. Furthermore, the performance of FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K=10B=3) is barely worsened compared with FedPG-BR (K=10𝐾10K=10) with 10 good agents. This shows that, with the adaptation of SCSG, our fault-tolerant FRL system can perfectly defend the VA attack from the literature, which further corroborates our analysis on our Byzantine filtering step (Section 3.3) showing that if gradients from Byzantine agents are not filtered out, their impact is limited since their maximum distance to ∇J​(𝜽0t)∇𝐽subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡0\nabla J(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}_{0}) is bounded by 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma (Claim D.2).

G.3 Environment Setup

On a Linux system, navigate into the root directory of this project and execute the following commands:

⬇
$ conda create -n FT-FRL pytorch=1.5.0
$ conda activate FT-FRL
$ pip install -r requirements.txt
$ cd codes

To run experiments in HalfCheetah, a mujoco license444http://www.mujoco.org is required. After obtaining the license, install the mujoco-py library by following the instructions from OpenAI.555https://github.com/openai/mujoco-py

G.4 Examples

To reproduce the results of FedPG-BR (K=10𝐾10K=10) in Figure 2 for the HalfCheetah task, run the following command:

⬇
$ python run.py --env_name HalfCheetah-v2 --FT_FedPG
--num_worker 10 --num_Byzantine 0
--log_dir ./logs_HalfCheetah --multiple_run 10
--run_name HalfCheetah_FT-FRL_W10B0

To reproduce the results of FedPG-BR (K=10​B=3𝐾10𝐵3K=10\ B=3) in Figure 3 where 3 Byzantine agents are Random Noise in the HalfCheetah task environment, run the following command:

⬇
$ python run.py --env_name CartPole-v1 --FT_FedPG
--num_worker 10 --num_Byzantine 3
--attack_type random-noise
--log_dir ./logs_Cartpole --multiple_run 10
--run_name Cartpole_FT-FRL_W10B3

Replace ‘--FT_FedPG’’ with ‘--SVRPG’’ for the results of SVRPG in the same experiment. All results including all statistics will be logged into the directory indicated by ‘--log_dir‘, which can be visualized in tensorboard.

To visualize the behavior of the learnt policy, run the experiment in evaluation mode with rendering option on. For example:

⬇
$ python run.py --env_name CartPole-v1 --FT_FedPG
--eval_only --render
--load_path PATH_TO_THE_SAVED_POLICY_MODEL
